subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] QS-SAMPA: a proposed format for plain-text Quickscript
msgSnippet: ... You will find ThothSampa here: http://openfontlibrary.org/media/files/phthenry/214 I don t know if we want to include senior QS in the news. I m also not
messageBody:
Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
>
>
> Excellent! Good choice of name, too. It will make it perfectly clear
> what mapping is being used--for those who've followed this thread,
> anyway. Have you included the alternate letters 'Noon' and 'Up'? I've
> been thinking that it would be straightforward to implement the rules
> for their use from pp 14-15 in the QM in your news program. It would
> be an easy first step towards Senior QS.
>


You will find ThothSampa here:

http://openfontlibrary.org/media/files/phthenry/214

I don't know if we want to include senior QS in the news. I'm also not
sure how to use these alternative forms of the letters, and it is my
understanding that implementing them would be very difficult. You only
use Noon depending on the previous letter, right? In order to get a font
to choose a letter based on the previous letter, you need to use an
Open type font, and not all applications support this type of substitution.

I used your letters for my ligatures. I would have liked to have the
font automatically generate ligature, but this too may be too hard to
do. I followed the instructions for fontforge, and then noticed at the
bottom of the page for these instructions that many applications won't
read ligature tables. Office, for example, won't. I did a quick search
on line, and it seems that True Type does not even support ligatures.
But John Cowan said the opposite, that it was more common for
applications to read the ligature table than the kerning table, so what
is going on here?

That brings up another slight problem, what to do with /3r/. In SAMPA,
/3r/ is of course expressed as /3r/, but right now in ThothSampa it is
represented as P. So if we are writing bird in an email, do we write

/b3rd/

or

/bPd/

or

/byrd/

?

I was hoping to create a ligature between 3 and r so that if one pasted
the text, one would see Earth, but I had no luck.

Paul
